articles.title: pkg-size: Find the True, Current Size of an npm Package Without Leaving Your Browser
articles.description: A beautifully designed site that can show you the true size of an npm package (including dependencies) using the actual packages which are 'installed' in a browser-based WebContainers-powered environment. Hiroki has üê¶ a Twitter thread where he explains more about how it works.
articles.author: Hiroki Osame

articles.title: TypeScript and the Dawn of Gradual Types
articles.description: From GitHub‚Äôs ReadME project comes a thorough journalistic take on how static typing made it into the JavaScript world, what TypeScript offers, some alternative approaches, and the possibility of adding type annotations to JavaScript iself.
articles.author: Mike Melanson (GitHub)

articles.title: Storybook 7.1: The Workshop for Building UI Components
articles.description: v7.1 introduces in-app onboarding for your newest team members, zero-config styling support for Tailwind, MUI, styled-components and MUI, Vue 3 source snippets, and more.
articles.author: Storybook Team

articles.title: Five Inconvenient Truths about TypeScript
articles.description: A brief dose of reality for a world seemingly obsessed with TypeScript: ‚ÄúIf you want to get into TypeScript, don‚Äôt think you can leave JavaScript behind. It will find you, and it will get you.‚Äù
articles.author: Stefan Baumgartner

articles.title: 'How We Generate JS and Python SDKs from a Canonical Rust¬†SDK'
articles.description: PostgresML is an extension that adds machine learning functions into Postgres. Its team loves and prefers Rust but most of its users are using JavaScript or Python. What to do? Simultaneously write multi-language libraries using Rust..
articles.author: Silas Marvin (PostgresML)

articles.title: Updating Code with jscodeshift
articles.description: TypeORM is an ORM for Node that introduced some breaking changes requiring the author to update lots of calls in his code. A perfect time to use a ‚Äòcodemod‚Äô to automate the job. Even if you don‚Äôt use TypeORM, this post might give you some ideas for other places to use such an approach.
articles.author: Clinton Blackburn

articles.title: How React 18 Improves App Performance
articles.description: If you‚Äôve not entirely kept up with how things have changed or developed in React with regards to concurrent rendering, transitions, Suspense, and even React Server Components, this is a fantastic review and primer to get up to speed on how React's newer features dramatically help with performance.
articles.author: Lydia Hallie (Vercel)

articles.title: wavesurfer.js 7: Audio Waveform Player
articles.description: If you‚Äôre creating a podcast player, audio experience, or anything where seeing an interactive audio waveform could be useful, check this out. GitHub repo.
articles.author: katspaugh and contributors

articles.title: TOAST UI Grid: A Customizable Grid Control for the Web
articles.description: A powerful MIT-licensed grid-style control for the display, editing, and management of data. It comes from the same folks as TUI Editor and TUI Calendar and while it‚Äôs happy on its own, there are wrappers for Vue and React too. GitHub repo.
articles.author: NHN

articles.title: Pines: A Library of UI Components for Alpine.js and Tailwind¬†Projects
articles.description: Includes sliders, tooltips, accordions, modals, and others. The CSS-only components are usable in any Tailwind project while the ones that require JS are designed for use with Alpine.js.
articles.author: devdojo

articles.title: YouTube.js 5.5: A Wrapper Around YouTube's Private API
articles.description: One of those things you'd expect to be quickly blocked somehow, but it's 18 months old, so... üòÜ The fun isn't just for Node or Deno users ‚Äì it'll work in the browser if you can proxy the requests through your own server.
articles.author: LuanRT

articles.title: Eruda 3.0: A Console for Mobile Browsers
articles.description: If you‚Äôre in a situation where you have no access to DevTools, you can add Eruda to your page and it provides a sort of virtual devtools you can use from any browser, including on mobile.
articles.author: LiriLiri

articles.title: Reagraph 4.10: WebGL Graph Visualization Library for¬†React
articles.description: Here‚Äôs a basic code example. This week‚Äôs release adds support for three dimensional clustering. GitHub repo.
articles.author: REAGRAPH

articles.title: brotli-wasm 2.0: A Brotli Compressor and Decompressor
articles.description: Covers both Node and the browser by means of WebAssembly.
articles.author: HTTP Toolkit

articles.title: Pacquet: A New, Experimental Package Manager for Node
articles.description: From a Node.js core member, no less.
articles.author: Yagiz Nizipli

articles.title: Chip Player JS: Browser-Based MIDIs, MODs and Game Music
articles.description: The creator of this site has, like me, a fascination with old digital music ‚Äì MIDI files, trackers, and the like. Rather than keep an old computer running, he decided to build a browser based music player for such files.
articles.author: Matt Montag

articles.description: Fresh 1.3 ‚Äì The Deno web framework. Plugins can now inject routes and middleware into apps, there's Deno.serve support, and you can create async route components.
Downshift 8.0 ‚Äì Primitives to build WAI-ARIA compliant React autocomplete, combobox & select components.
Node.js v18.17.0 (LTS) ‚Äì Node 18 gets the Ada 2.0 WHATWG URL parser.
Fastify 4.20 ‚Äì The fast, low overhead web Node.js framework.
The Promise.withResolvers proposal has progressed from stage 2 to 3 at TC39, as has the array grouping proposal, as well as source phase imports.

üó£ The folks on Hacker News discussed why the site isn't being indundated with links to new JavaScript frameworks recently. Has React 'won'? Has AI stolen the limelight? Or is a JavaScript revolution quietly brewing..?
üë¥üèª A blog post from 1996 popped up telling us about the newest JavaScript features in Netscape 3.0 ‚Äì definitely a blast from the past. Say hello to the typeof operator!

articles.title: What Is Page Bloat? And How Is It Hurting Your Search Rank and Users?
articles.description: A thorough bit of research into how the Web's pages have only continued to grow (complete with images, video, JavaScript, etc.), why this bloat is bad, and how to track and fight its upward creep.
articles.author: Tammy Everts

articles.title: Writing CSS in 2023: Is It Any Different to a Few Years Ago?
articles.description: Yep, CSS is evolving faster than ever. So. with all these new features, and more on the way, how we write CSS is naturally evolving, too. Here, Geoff shares which features have had the most influence on his current approaches to CSS (no Tailwind here, surprisingly).
articles.author: Geoff Graham (Smashing Magazine)

articles.title: üôÇ Using Emoji on the Web
articles.description: It was World Emoji Day earlier this week (yes, that‚Äôs a thing) so here‚Äôs a good look at using them on the web: ‚Äúprobably more than you ever wanted to know about emoji‚Äù.
articles.author: Ollie Williams

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Getting Started with CSS Nesting
articles.description: Native nesting support is now available in all major browsers, as such Kevin shares a thorough look at it. A good resource to get you started using this new tool to increase the modularity and maintainability of your CSS.
articles.author: Kevin Powell

articles.title: CSS Findings from the Threads App
articles.description: Ahmad goes spelunking through Meta‚Äôs new Threads app to see what interesting CSS findings can be gleaned ‚Äî such as them using CSS Grid for the post layout.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: A Case Study on Scroll-Driven Animation Performance
articles.description: A look at how a new set of browser APIs to natively support scroll-driven animations are making for a much smoother experience compared to the classic way of implementing them.
articles.author: Yuriko Hirota

articles.title: Three Common Types of Test Automation
articles.description: Explores how to plan the right strategy for testing via two general testing modes and three common types of test automation.
articles.author: Ramona Schwering

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Advanced Positioning in CSS Grid
articles.description: A practical, in-depth guide to positioning elements on CSS Grid exactly as you want ‚Äî Covers how grid-row and grid-column work in detail.
articles.author: Zoran Jambor

articles.title: Visually Hidden Links with 0 Dimensions
articles.description: Ever wondered why visually-hidden links have a height/weight that‚Äôs set 1px? Manuel shares the reason why‚Ä¶
articles.author: Manuel Matuzoviƒá

articles.title: Creating an Animated SVG Logo
articles.description: A quick look at how to achieve a nice animated logo - the end result here is slick.
articles.author: Anthony Fu

articles.title: Flexer: A CSS Flexbox Playground
articles.description: You probably don‚Äôt need another Flexbox playground but this one is simple and has an interesting feature: You can select ‚ÄúActual‚Äù (for the literal property names) or ‚ÄúSimplified‚Äù (which is good for better understanding).
articles.author: Idan Ram

articles.title: Driver.js: Tours, Highlights, Contextual Help, and More
articles.description: A no-dependency, vanilla JavaScript library for putting together on-page tours and contextual help systems. There are lots of examples to check out ‚Äì it‚Äôs really smooth.
articles.author: Kamran Ahmed

articles.title: Pines: A Library of UI Components for Alpine.js and Tailwind¬†Projects
articles.description: Includes sliders, tooltips, accordions, modals, and others. The CSS-only components are usable in any Tailwind project while the ones that require JS are designed for use with Alpine.js.
articles.author: devdojo

articles.title: Standardized Audio Context: A Cross-Browser Web Audio API¬†Wrapper
articles.description: A side effect-free abstraction over a subset of the Web Audio API that works reliably across all mainstream browsers.
articles.author: Christoph Guttandin

articles.title: React Content Font: Create Custom Google Fonts from Page¬†Content
articles.description: Fonts covering certain alphabets and languages can be particularly big (e.g. Noto Sans Japanese is almost 6 megabytes). What if you could request a font from Google Fonts containing only the characters you need?
articles.author: Adam Butterfield

articles.title: Free Faces: A Curated Collection of Free Typefaces
articles.description: The links are to a number of different font repositories around the web, so be sure to check each font‚Äôs usage license to ensure they‚Äôre web friendly.
articles.author: simon foster

articles.description: You can now test and experiment with WordPress directly in the browser thanks to the new WordPress Playground. This uses more Web magic than you might think: PHP runs as a WebAssembly binary, as does SQLite, and a service worker plays the role of Web server.
Wix is launching an AI tool to to create 'entire websites' via prompts.
Fancy playing Wordle directly from the browser address bar? It's possible.
Calibri is out and Aptos is in as Microsoft's new default font.
You'll need to squint a bit, but the raw data from Mozilla's benchmarks seems to show Firefox passing Chromium performance wise in recent weeks?
Congrats to Hidde de Vries who is now a member of the CSS Working Group.
